data.output: As I walked along the ruined banks of the polluted river, the stench of diesel was almost overpowering. The devastation of this habitat since the pump had malfunctioned and spewed waste was almost complete. I could have wept in memory of the past beauty that was lost. The glorious verdant and lush vegetation, the dazzling colours of the flowers; even the flash of the petrol blue feathers of a rare kingfisher.

I could hear the stamp of the soldiers' boots as they marched past my cottage. Their uniforms neat and precise, each young man appearing much as the last. I wondered to myself what differences lay under the outer layers which gave them such a singular appearance. Perhaps one wore lady's underwear! I chuckled to myself. Perhaps there was a lover's letter tucked inside a pocket, penned in secret and hidden away until a chance to send it.

The notes hung in the air, almost alive as they echoed around the cathedral. The beauty of an organ when played by a master is an unparalleled delight. I did not know the name of the piece, it was grand and almost military, perhaps a tribute to an empire long since lost to time. It certainly didn't comply with the playlist set for Michaelmas term this year, as I knew all those compositions by heart.

Marcus peered through the gloom. "Why were there no lights?" he wondered, as he cupped his hands against the window to try and see inside the house. Perhaps the family had failed to make their payment, but without power in the midst of this winter, the family would suffer fatally. There was no sign of life inside, and Marcus prayed silently they had moved on before the freeze and weren't to be found inside. Once, there were charities to help and places to go, but in these no longer exist: too many require help, and no one has any left to give.
